title: For Sale:  Rossi Youth Combo - .22 LR and .410 Shotgun
location: Mazoish or meet in Madison, Madison, Wisconsin
postcontent:
This combo has been a great learning tool for my kids. I’m selling it reluctantly, but she-who-must-be-obeyed says it has to go if I want to equip the eldest with a competition rifle. So here we go…

This is a single-shot, break action combo with a .22 rifle barrel and a .410 shotgun barrel. The rifle barrel has relatively nice partridge sights and obviously can take .22 short as well (a nice feature for noise levels). The shotgun barrel is smoothbore with the customary front bead sight. The trigger breaks cleanly at 5.5 lbs, which I have found to be good for kids learning safety. It’s not a target trigger, obviously, but these aren’t target sights either and it does teach control. 

I’m also including an extra-short buttstock I made. Some of these “youth” stocks apparently have rather large youths in mind. Young girls frequently need something shorter, and in this case it is included. It is easy to change with a ½” socket on an extension. Another benefit of this is that the shorter stock allows for a substantial recoil pad for learning shotgun. It is good to avoid teaching kids to flinch! (That part isn’t included, but any strap-on recoil pad should work.) 

This combo has very few rounds through it, mostly because we ended up spending so much more time with an air rifle. Consequently it is in very nice shape. It also comes with a well-thought-out padded nylon carry case. Maybe now would be a good time to think ahead toward the holidays? Or a first hunting season? 

The usual legal nonsense…Face to face only, bill of sale and WI driver’s license required.

Asking $150

title: For Sale:  Thompson Contender super 14" in 357 max
location: Onalaska Lewis County, Southwest Washington, Washington
postcontent:
The title say it all. The gun is a 14" chambered in 357max. I am listing this for a friend who is going on and out of state hunt. It comes ready to mount a scope with both bases and rings. It has wood grips and a pachmyer forend. I have added some info on the 357 max.

The .357 Maximum, formally known as the .357 Remington Maximum or the .357 Max, is a super magnum handgun cartridge originally developed by Elgin Gates as the wildcat .357 SuperMag.[1] The .357 Maximum was introduced into commercial production as a joint-venture by Remington Arms Company and Ruger in 1983 as a new chambering for the Ruger Blackhawk.[2] Shortly thereafter, Dan Wesson Firearms and Thompson/Center Arms introduced firearms in this cartridge. United Sporting Arms chambered it in their Silhouette series single-action revolvers. It is a .357 Magnum case lengthened .300".[3] Based on the .357 Magnum cartridge, a revolver or single-shot pistol designed for the .357 Max can fire .357 Magnum, and .38 Special rounds. Intended primarily as a silhouette cartridge, such high velocity and energy levels have hunting applications.[2] SAAMI pressure level for this cartridge is set at 48,000 CUP.[2]

Despite stellar performance, the high pressure and velocity of the cartridge caused flame cutting of revolver top straps (due to the use of light 110 and 125 grain bullets), and the cartridge has since been dropped by all manufacturers who so chambered their revolvers.[4] Single shot pistols and rifles (e.g., Thompson/Center Contender) are still available in this caliber, and remain popular among handloaders.[2] Unprimed brass is still produced every few years by Remington.

title: For Sale:  Kimber Ultra Carry with Crimson Trace
postcontent:
I have a Kimber Ultra Carry with Crimson Trace Rosewood grips that I no long am using as a daily carry.

OK details about the Kimber and its story. I am the 3rd owner of this gun. I know the other 2 owners, they are coworkers. The first owner sold it before he filed for divorce from his wife. He was more of a collector when it came to 1911's. I actually tried to buy it then, but missed out. The second owner only had it for a few months. He bought it with thoughts of it being his daily carry. However he is a long time competition shooter and did not care for the shorter grip and barrel. He went back to a full size 1911 for his daily carry. That is when I bought it. I carried it a lot. Its a sweet looking gun. The all satin black gun with satin chrome controls and the rosewood crimson trace grips just make it look like something special. I have never seen this color configuration from Kimber, but the original owner says he bought it that way either from gander mountain or buds gun shop. He can't remember. To his best memory he bought it new about 3 years ago. I had the gun appraised at The Sportsmans stop in Elmore, Ohio. He did mention that it was most likely a special order because of the color configuration. The front checkering is an insert that goes under grips from side to side it is an add on.

OK the gun Kimber Ultra Carry II 45acp with Crimson Trace Rosewood grips 
3" barrel 
7+1 magazines 
Original case 
I have had no feeding or ejecting issues with the gun at all. I have ran quite a few different FMJ ammo through it and 3 or 4 types of JHP. I may have put 150 rounds through it myself. The second owner loaded it with Hornady Critical Defence shot 1 or 2 mags reloaded the one mag and carried it. From what the original owner tells me he shot a few boxes of FMJ through it to brake it in and then a box of federal hydrashocks. So total round count on the gun? My guess is 450-650.

You should be able to copy and paste this into your browser. 
https://picasaweb.google.com/REDACTEDREDACTED3/KimberUltraCarry? authuser=0&feat=directlink

Sorry I could not get the pictures uploaded. 
f the link does not work. I can email or text them to you.
If you need any other information about it please ask. I will do my best to answer.

title: For Sale:  Polish P64 Military Pistol in 9mm Makarov 9x18mm
postcontent:
For sale is a Polish P64 Military Pistol in 9mm Makarov 9x18mm with two 6 round magazines and over 60 rounds of ammunition.   

The firearm has been Dura-Coated with a Coyote Tan and Green Camouflage pattern.  Before Dura-Coating several of my tactical rifles I did this little handgun for practice.  It turned out quite nice.   

The handgun does have a lighter spring for lighter double action trigger pull, which makes it nice for an inexpensive carry gun or back-up.  

It has a cracked left panel on the grip but it has been repaired from the inside and it’s solid.  Grip panels and parts are very inexpensive if someone wishes to replace.   It makes a good inside the vehicle gun as a back-up piece for personal protection, with your Carry Permit of course.  It also makes a good inexpensive carry piece for those on a budget.   

The gun is dated with a 1976 production date and is a surplus firearm from Poland.    It’s a great little shooter highly accurate and fun.   Handgun comes with 2 mags, over 60 rounds of 9x18mm, and a nice soft case.  

$150 cash private local sale in the Minneapolis/St Paul Metro area (south metro preferred) 
Text, email or call - 952*215*4016

History of the P-64:  

The P-64 pistol (official designation 9 mm pistolet wz. 1964) has been developed in Poland during late 1950s and early 1960s, as a compact and lightweight replacement for Tokarev TT pistols, manufactured in Poland under soviet license. Following the Soviet road, Poland replaced the powerful 7.62x25mm ammunition with less powerful, but still effective 9x18 Makarov ammunition. P-64 has been used by both Polish military and police, and still could be found in holsters of some Polish police officers. In military service it has been superseded in mid-1980s by the P-83 pistol. The P-64 was small and light enough for a pocket or a concealed carry sidearm, but it has too small magazine, and too heavy trigger pull to be considered as a valuable service pistol.

P-64 is a blowback operated, semi-automatic weapon, made almost entirely of steel. P-64 is hammer fired, with double-action trigger and de-cocking safety, mounted at the left side of the slide. Safety features also include loaded chamber indicator in the form of a small pin, which protrudes from the back of the slide, above the hammer, when chamber is loaded with cartridge. Trigger guard is a separate unit, which is hinged to the frame and served as a disassembly lever when pulled down. Single stack magazine contains only 6 rounds, and magazine release catch is located at the bottom of the grip.

http://www.p64resource.com/

title: For Sale:  Glock 37 GEN 3
postcontent:
The Glock 37 was the genesis for the 45 GAP (Glock Automatic Pistol) round. The GAP round features a shorter case than traditional 45 ACP resulting in the ability to use a smaller frame and grip to house the magazine. However, a smaller case does not equal less stopping power. The GAP operates at higher pressure than the ACP providing results on par with the traditional load.

This particular GEN 3 G37 has an extremely low round count and is basically new.  Unfortunately, the box and papers were lost so what you see in pictures is what is available.  It is outfitted with a Glock adjustable rear sight and Glock extended slide release. It comes with two 10 round magazines and enough Magtech 230gr JHP rounds to load them both.  May trade for +/- cash for something interesting.

Terms: FTF, CCW/IN DL, and Bill of Sale

title: For Sale:  Kimber 1911 Ultra Carry with Crimson Trace
postcontent:
I have a Kimber 1911 Ultra Carry with Crimson Trace Rosewood grips that I no long am using as a daily carry.

OK details about the Kimber and its story. I am the 3rd owner of this gun. I know the other 2 owners, they are coworkers. The first owner sold it before he filed for divorce from his wife. He was more of a collector when it came to 1911's. I actually tried to buy it then, but missed out. The second owner only had it for a few months. He bought it with thoughts of it being his daily carry. However he is a long time competition shooter and did not care for the shorter grip and barrel. He went back to a full size 1911 for his daily carry. That is when I bought it. I carried it a lot. Its a sweet looking gun. The all satin black gun with satin chrome controls and the rosewood crimson trace grips just make it look like something special. I have never seen this color configuration from Kimber, but the original owner says he bought it that way either from gander mountain or buds gun shop. He can't remember. To his best memory he bought it new about 3 years ago. I had the gun appraised at The Sportsmans stop in Elmore, Ohio. He did mention that it was most likely a special order because of the color configuration. The front checkering is an insert that goes under grips from side to side it is an add on.

OK the gun Kimber Ultra Carry II 45acp with Crimson Trace Rosewood grips 
3" barrel 
7+1 magazines 
Original case 
I have had no feeding or ejecting issues with the gun at all. I have ran quite a few different FMJ ammo through it and 3 or 4 types of JHP. I may have put 150 rounds through it myself. The second owner loaded it with Hornady Critical Defence shot 1 or 2 mags reloaded the one mag and carried it. From what the original owner tells me he shot a few boxes of FMJ through it to brake it in and then a box of federal hydrashocks. So total round count on the gun? My guess is 450-650.

You should be able to copy and paste this into your browser. 
https://picasaweb.google.com/110603633925801344793/KimberUltraCarry? authuser=0&feat=directlink

Sorry I could not get the pictures uploaded. 
f the link does not work. I can email or text them to you.
 If you need any other information about it please ask. I will do my best to answer.

Asking $925

Tony
 419-two one five-964 zero

Springfield XDm 4.5 45acp
Maybe an AR-15.
Thats it. I prefer cash.

title: For Sale/Trade:  AK-47, Ruger SS SP-101 w/CT Laser grips + Nikon Camera
postcontent:
I have a SS Ruger .357 SP-101 with Crimson Trace grips, a Zastava AK-47 plus a Nikon digital camera. All three items are in excellent condition and have had  little wear or use.   Camera comes with Nikon DX 18-55mm zoom af lens, strap, Expedition Outfitters gadget bag and Nikon strap. Equipment is in excellent condition. No issues - it takes beautiful, HD "shots." 

 The .357 with CC grips is worth over $600 (the grips cost over $200 new) but I have it listed for a measly $550. 

The AK-47 has only had a few hundred rounds through it. 

You can see a video of me shooting it (unsupported but still mostly hitting) 100 + yrd 10-inch steel targets @ http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AGRjjrxKbG8&feature=plcp  My son and I both were hitting a 12 inch steel plate at 200 yards. This is a great rifle but I have 7.62x39 weapons and am a big fan of that caliber but I want a RRA SOCOM upper to hunt with this year. It is listed for $395 firm. 

So the Ruger is $550 firm (comes in orig. box, with speed loader, owners manual and holster and lock); $395 for the AK47 with a spare magazine and $275 for the camera and accessories. 

More photos are available upon request in exchange for clear photos of your equipment .   

Want to trade some of or all the above described equipment for a quality RRA SOCOM upper. If you have something else in mind, send clear photos to REDACTED 

NOW BEFORE CONTACTING ME... PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING...

===================================================

When I first came on Armslist I sold a gun or two and bought a couple with no problems. Beginners luck! At that time I would come across ads with fine print like I am about to write and think... "Wow, what a grumpy attitude."

Since then I have had my time wasted over and over by people who boldly make offers and as soon as they are accepted disappear or begin modifying them. 

You are free to make whatever offer you feel is fair and we can talk about it. But, as a matter of principle, once I agree to an offer, I will not budge an inch. Period. 

Please don't make an offer you don't have the money to cover. I just don't get it. What is the point?

If you offer a fair price and I accept it, don't just assume I would have taken less. I don't tend to dicker around a lot. 

Please do your research before making an offer. I am not offended when someone contacts me and says, "Hey, I can buy this from www.acmeguns.com (or whatever) for $XXX." Prices vary and recently I found I really was asking too much for a gun given what they currently sell for elsewhere new. I adjusted the price. However, please, please, please make sure the price you quote are for IN STOCK guns. Gun dealers can put any crazy price they want on OUT OF STOCK GUNS! Also make sure you add in transfer, shipping and handling fees if they apply. Anyone can put a cheap price on the tag if they are going to recoup the discount on the way out the door. Just saying... don't get in too big of a rush to say you can get it somewhere else cheaper when you really cannot. 

I prefer FTF deals. I will absorb no part of shipping including my gas. (Plan on adding about $35 to the price) I will not send until I have money in my hand. No exceptions. If you send a check, it has to clear before I ship. Sorry but that's the deal. 

If you want to offer a trade, send clear pictures of your item(s) to REDACTED Please understand that my goal in considering a trade will most likely be to obtain something I can get MORE money (MORE than $550) to apply to the purchase of the SOCOM upper. So don't be offended if I say no to an otherwise "fair" trade, okay? (Why else would I go to the trouble of doing a trade for something I have to re-list etc?

BOTTOM-LINE All I hope for is that folks will be fair and act responsibly. I can promise you this, once I say, text or email the word DEAL ... that's it. I was raised that your word is your bond and I have been offered better deals after accepting an offer and it doesn't turn my head. Once I sold a rifle and then discovered the sight on it was worth over half my asking price by itself. I should have done more research ... my bad... out the door it went. Somethings (like your name or character) are more important than money but hey, not all of us were raised the same and I have plenty of faults of my own. 

Thanks for looking and all the best to you.
